The first day we will review the pre-work completion and introduce a more evolved CSS that enables amazing layouts and the amazing Bootstrap framework that will make you life so much easier with the "component oriented" approach.","key-concepts":["Everything is text","Always be closing","Client vs Server","HTTP request vs response","HTML vs CSS","DRY Technique","Component","Display block vs flex"],"teacher_instructions":"Students know already basic CSS and HTML, just go over the concepts really fast but stop and explain carefully the Display and Position rules, specifically talk about the FlexBox as the main tool to build layouts. Then, explain Bootstrap and how it solves 99% of the pain: everything is a component from now on"","extended_instructions":"# The Internet, HTML, CSS and Bootstrap ## `20 min` Small presentation about the bootcamp, [click here to open it](https://docs.google.com/presentation/d/1--0xX43xyfngGTWVQEgmcbLuE7QCCz-jovL2JBOEPY0/edit#slide=id.g555ffcabca_1_0). ## `15 min` Play a game to get to know each other. - Everyone writes in an anonimus piece of paper with something about themselves. E.g: "I like dogs" or "I work on sales", etc. - Put all papers inside a cup and start the game. - Choose one student to start introducing himself: - First name and last. - What would you like to be called? - What do you do now? (for work) - What do you plan on doing when you become a developer? - Then, that student must pick one random paper from the cup and guess how is the person that wrote it. - After guessing, the person who wrote it must come next and introduce himself and pick another paper... etc. ## `5 min` Present the team Everyone introduces himself: Chief of Admissions, Chief of Career Support, Chief of Education, Main instructor, and teacher assistant. ## `15 min` Install the tools Start with Gitpod, invite all students, and make sure they are able to create workspaces and what the academy boilerplates are. ## `10 min` Go over prework concepts really fast Check if the students completed the prework, if ~70% of the students finished the prework you can continue with the rest of the class, otherwise you will have to postpone today's topics and today's focus only con starting/completing the prework projects and concepts with the students. ## If 70% of the students completed the prework you can continue with the rest of the day: ### How does the internet works? 1. The world is divided between servers and clients. 2. We call "clients" the computers with browsers or mobile apps. 3. We call servers where the centralized database is. ### HTTP Request vs Response** - The rules used for this client-sever communication is called HTTP, which stands for Hyper Text Transfer Protocol. - The way that you get the website is by sending a "Request" to the server. This tells the server what website or resource you are looking to view/use. The server then responds with the information. - The server then sends a response, which tells will confirm the receipt of the request and let your computer know that it will begin sending data. - This back and forth process will continue with more Request=>Response pairs until you have finished loading your remote resource. ### Everything is text! - With HTTP, it’s important to focus on the first T in the acronym, which stands for `Text`. In this protocol, everything is sent back and forth as TEXT. - While there are other protocols out there, for now, we want to remember that with HTTP – Everything is TEXT. - Make students open a picture with Notepad/TextEdit they will see the text that represents the image. ### Browser Interpretation - After your browser uses the HTTP protocol and receives the data as text, it then has the job of interpreting that text and converting it to the correct visual format. #### HTML - The first TEXT-based format we will see is HTML. - HTML its all about `` you open and close tags to give them basic format. - There are a lot of HTML tags but you only have to know a few and you can always google them. - Explain the basic tags like `

`,`

`,``,``, headings (`

`,`

`,etc). [[demo]] | :point_up: The most important thing to remember in HTML is to ALWAYS BE CLOSING! #### Always Be Closing and Indentation Matters** - Everything is going to be done in blocks of code. - First you open the block, then you close the block. ### CSS vs HTML ```css #id_selector { property: value; } .class_selector { property: value; } tag_selector { property: value; } ``` ## `20 min` Start the new content: Advanced CSS ### Specificity - Do not use ID as CSS selectors (use specificity). - The class selector is the most used because it can be reused all over your website. - Show this [video that explains](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=In78mSOHmls) specificity to the class. - Combine selectors to get more specific about which element you are styling - Ask if anyone remembers what we said DRY Programming means? Don’t repeat yourself. You may think it’s funny that they call the opposite of DRY - WET programming, which they have given the following titles to: "write everything twice", "we enjoy typing" or "waste everyone's time"** ### Box Model - Box layout means that most elements can be thought of as boxes: with margin, padding, with and height. - There are 4 main parts to the typical box model: (draw the following on the board or show picture from breathcode) - Content: this is what is inside the box - Padding: this is spacing between the border and content (inside box also) - Border: this is the edge of the box - Margin: this is spacing between the outside of the box and the next element over in any direction. (which could be the edge of the page, another div, a paragraph, or even an image) - You can also have a background color or image, this will show in the content area of your box. #### The Display Property: - Compare `display:block` vs `display:inline`: Display block its what makes an element behave like a box, inline elements have no margins. - Compare `display:block` vs `display:inline-block`. - Display: flex; its the main tool for building complex layouts because it easily allows having several divs on the same line (columns). - I recommend going over the CSS and HTML [cheat sheets that we have available on the breathco.de platform under Assets](https://breatheco.de/assets/). ## Display Flex and how important it is. Take some time to explain display:flex and how it is used on today's project. #### The Position Property: - Position:fixed follows the user, it is mainly used for anoying modals or popups. - If one element has position:relative must always be companioned by one or more childs with position:absolute. Its broadly used for relating two elements to each other (one follows the other) - Compare `display:block` vs `display:inline-block`. ## `2:30 hr` Start the project! Read the instructions out loud with the class, make sure they understand. Students must start discussing on the whiteboard a strategy about the project. - From top to bottom identify the tags you will be using. - When to use `display:inline-block` and/or `position:absolute` or `position:relative`. - Setup the project with one `index.html` and one `styles.css` ## `20 min` Bootstrap ### What is bootstrap? Just a predefined stylesheet inveted by [a guy at twitter (Mark Otto)](https://twitter.com/mdo?lang=en). ### Why? - Because doing styles is repetitive, it was about time someone did a boilerplate. - Its component oriented. - It makes websites easier and faster to build. ### Bootstrap versions & download Bootstrap has many versions, always check if you are using the last version of Bootstrap on your project, here you can find all the available versions: [https://getbootstrap.com/docs/versions/](https://getbootstrap.com/docs/versions/) We recomend using a CDN to import bootstrap in your HTML like this one: [https://www.bootstrapcdn.com/](https://www.bootstrapcdn.com/) ### The Most Important (Used) Components 1. Navbar 2. Card 3. Modal: https://getbootstrap.com/docs/4.0/components/modal/#live-demo ### The Basic Workflow (asuming you have a wireframe or design) 1. Build your basic layout with the Grid (container, row and collumns) 1. Identify the components you will need (use piece of paper) 2. Copy & Paste the component code into your website. 3. Customize the component for your specific design. 4. Adjust anything else overriding with css styles on your own sylesheet. 5. Remember the utility classes to avoid doing to much custom CSS. ### Helper/Utility Classes that come with bootstrap* These are classes you can attach that do things such as control margin or padding, control borders, or even float elements. For example, if you wanted no margin on the left of the element, you can add the class ml-0 to the element and it will set the left margin to zero. ### Layout using Grid system - Explain 12 column layout and how it works - every line is a Row - this row holds columns as immediate childs - every Row on a page has 12 columns - columns are equally measured in percentages so they are responsive. - the basic sizes are: col, col-xs, col-sm, col-md, col-lg, col-xl ### Bootstrap does not have fonts or icons We use google fonts and font awesome for that. ## `2:30min` Have class work on bootstrap instagram. - Students gather in pairs tos strategize first (best practice) - Read instructions out loud and have them build a strategy - Have them identify the components. Do not talk more, they will not be able to process it because they are overwhelmed, just help them code. Answer questions individually with your teacher assistants. {"slug":"full-stack.v4","profile":"full-stack","label":"Full Stack PT","description":"","version":4,"academy_author":"4","days":[{"id":1,"label":"HTML/CSS/Bootstrap","lessons":[{"title":"Introduction to 4Geeks Academy","slug":"intro-to-4geeks"},{"title":"What is HTML? It's time to learn HTML and its structure","slug":"what-is-html-learn-html"},{"title":"Learn CSS: What is CSS Meant for?","slug":"what-is-css-learn-css"},{"title":"CSS Layouts: Create and Build Layouts with CSS","slug":"css-layouts"},{"title":"Mastering CSS Selectors","slug":"mastering-css-selectors"},{"title":"Bootstrap Tutorial: Learn Bootstrap 4 in 10 minutes","slug":"bootstrap-tutorial-of-bootstrap-4"}],"project":{"title":"Digital Postcard","instructions":"https://projects.breatheco.de/project/postcard"},"quizzes":[{"title":"Bootstrap","slug":"bootstrap-quiz"}],"replits":[{"title":"Learn CSS Interactively","slug":"css-exercises"},{"title":"Learn HTML Forms","slug":"forms-exercises"},{"title":"Learn Bootstrap Tutorial","slug":"bootstrap-exercises"}],"homework":"Students must finish their project and must remember to read the next lesson before next class.","position":1,"assignments":[{"slug":"postcard","title":"Digital Postcard"},{"slug":"instagram-post","title":"Instagram Post"},{"slug":"instagram-feed","title":"Simple Instagram Photo Feed with HTML/CSS"},{"slug":"instagram-feed-bootstrap","title":"Instagram Photo Feed with Bootstrap"}],"description":"During the pre-work you learn some basic CSS and HTML, and hopefully how to use the flex-box to create simple layouts. The first day we will review the pre-work completion and introduce a more evolved CSS that enables amazing layouts and the amazing Bootstrap framework that will make you life so much easier with the "component oriented" approach.","key-concepts":["Everything is text","Always be closing","Client vs Server","HTTP request vs response","HTML vs CSS","DRY Technique","Flex Box","Bootstrap","Component","Workflow: Identify Component, Copy&Paste, the customize it","Helper/utility Clasees that come with Bootstrap"],"teacher_instructions":"Students know already basic CSS and HTML, just go over the concepts really fast but stop and explain carefully the Display and Position rules, specifically talk about the FlexBox as the main tool to build layouts. Then, explain Bootstrap and how it solves 99% of the pain: everything is a component from now on"","extended_instructions":"# The Internet, HTML, CSS and Bootstrap ## `20 min` Small presentation about the bootcamp, [click here to open it](https://docs.google.com/presentation/d/1--0xX43xyfngGTWVQEgmcbLuE7QCCz-jovL2JBOEPY0/edit#slide=id.g555ffcabca_1_0). ## `15 min` Play a game to get to know each other. - Everyone writes in an anonimus piece of paper with something about themselves. E.g: "I like dogs" or "I work on sales", etc. - Put all papers inside a cup and start the game. - Choose one student to start introducing himself: - First name and last. - What would you like to be called? - What do you do now? (for work) - What do you plan on doing when you become a developer? - Then, that student must pick one random paper from the cup and guess how is the person that wrote it. - After guessing, the person who wrote it must come next and introduce himself and pick another paper... etc. ## `5 min` Present the team Everyone introduces himself: Chief of Admissions, Chief of Career Support, Chief of Education, Main instructor, and teacher assistant. ## `15 min` Install the tools Start with Gitpod, invite all students, and make sure they are able to create workspaces and what the academy boilerplates are. ## `10 min` Go over prework concepts really fast Check if the students completed the prework, if ~70% of the students finished the prework you can continue with the rest of the class, otherwise you will have to postpone today's topics and today's focus only con starting/completing the prework projects and concepts with the students. ## If 70% of the students completed the prework you can continue with the rest of the day: ### How does the internet works? 1. The world is divided between servers and clients. 2. We call "clients" the computers with browsers or mobile apps. 3. We call servers where the centralized database is. ### HTTP Request vs Response** - The rules used for this client-sever communication is called HTTP, which stands for Hyper Text Transfer Protocol. - The way that you get the website is by sending a "Request" to the server. This tells the server what website or resource you are looking to view/use. The server then responds with the information. - The server then sends a response, which tells will confirm the receipt of the request and let your computer know that it will begin sending data. - This back and forth process will continue with more Request=>Response pairs until you have finished loading your remote resource. ### Everything is text! - With HTTP, it’s important to focus on the first T in the acronym, which stands for `Text`. In this protocol, everything is sent back and forth as TEXT. - While there are other protocols out there, for now, we want to remember that with HTTP – Everything is TEXT. - Make students open a picture with Notepad/TextEdit they will see the text that represents the image. ### Browser Interpretation - After your browser uses the HTTP protocol and receives the data as text, it then has the job of interpreting that text and converting it to the correct visual format. #### HTML - The first TEXT-based format we will see is HTML. - HTML its all about `` you open and close tags to give them basic format. - There are a lot of HTML tags but you only have to know a few and you can always google them. - Explain the basic tags like `

`,`

`,``,``, headings (`

`,`

`,etc). [[demo]] | :point_up: The most important thing to remember in HTML is to ALWAYS BE CLOSING! #### Always Be Closing and Indentation Matters** - Everything is going to be done in blocks of code. - First you open the block, then you close the block. ### CSS vs HTML ```css #id_selector { property: value; } .class_selector { property: value; } tag_selector { property: value; } ``` ## `20 min` Start the new content: Advanced CSS ### Specificity - Do not use ID as CSS selectors (use specificity). - The class selector is the most used because it can be reused all over your website. - Show this [video that explains](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=In78mSOHmls) specificity to the class. - Combine selectors to get more specific about which element you are styling - Ask if anyone remembers what we said DRY Programming means? Don’t repeat yourself. You may think it’s funny that they call the opposite of DRY - WET programming, which they have given the following titles to: "write everything twice", "we enjoy typing" or "waste everyone's time"** ### Box Model - Box layout means that most elements can be thought of as boxes: with margin, padding, with and height. - There are 4 main parts to the typical box model: (draw the following on the board or show picture from breathcode) - Content: this is what is inside the box - Padding: this is spacing between the border and content (inside box also) - Border: this is the edge of the box - Margin: this is spacing between the outside of the box and the next element over in any direction. (which could be the edge of the page, another div, a paragraph, or even an image) - You can also have a background color or image, this will show in the content area of your box. #### The Display Property: - Compare `display:block` vs `display:inline`: Display block its what makes an element behave like a box, inline elements have no margins. - Compare `display:block` vs `display:inline-block`. - Display: flex; its the main tool for building complex layouts because it easily allows having several divs on the same line (columns). - I recommend going over the CSS and HTML [cheat sheets that we have available on the breathco.de platform under Assets](https://breatheco.de/assets/). ## Display Flex and how important it is. Take some time to explain display:flex and how it is used on today's project. #### The Position Property: - Position:fixed follows the user, it is mainly used for anoying modals or popups. - If one element has position:relative must always be companioned by one or more childs with position:absolute. Its broadly used for relating two elements to each other (one follows the other) - Compare `display:block` vs `display:inline-block`. ## `2:30 hr` Start the project! Read the instructions out loud with the class, make sure they understand. Students must start discussing on the whiteboard a strategy about the project. - From top to bottom identify the tags you will be using. - When to use `display:inline-block` and/or `position:absolute` or `position:relative`. - Setup the project with one `index.html` and one `styles.css` ## `20 min` Bootstrap ### What is bootstrap? Just a predefined stylesheet inveted by [a guy at twitter (Mark Otto)](https://twitter.com/mdo?lang=en). ### Why? - Because doing styles is repetitive, it was about time someone did a boilerplate. - Its component oriented. - It makes websites easier and faster to build. ### Bootstrap versions & download Bootstrap has many versions, always check if you are using the last version of Bootstrap on your project, here you can find all the available versions: [https://getbootstrap.com/docs/versions/](https://getbootstrap.com/docs/versions/) We recomend using a CDN to import bootstrap in your HTML like this one: [https://www.bootstrapcdn.com/](https://www.bootstrapcdn.com/) ### The Most Important (Used) Components 1. Navbar 2. Card 3. Modal: https://getbootstrap.com/docs/4.0/components/modal/#live-demo ### The Basic Workflow (asuming you have a wireframe or design) 1. Build your basic layout with the Grid (container, row and collumns) 1. Identify the components you will need (use piece of paper) 2. Copy & Paste the component code into your website. 3. Customize the component for your specific design. 4. Adjust anything else overriding with css styles on your own sylesheet. 5. Remember the utility classes to avoid doing to much custom CSS. ### Helper/Utility Classes that come with bootstrap* These are classes you can attach that do things such as control margin or padding, control borders, or even float elements. For example, if you wanted no margin on the left of the element, you can add the class ml-0 to the element and it will set the left margin to zero. ### Layout using Grid system - Explain 12 column layout and how it works - every line is a Row - this row holds columns as immediate childs - every Row on a page has 12 columns - columns are equally measured in percentages so they are responsive. - the basic sizes are: col, col-xs, col-sm, col-md, col-lg, col-xl ### Bootstrap does not have fonts or icons We use google fonts and font awesome for that. ## `2:30min` Have class work on bootstrap instagram. - Students gather in pairs tos strategize first (best practice) - Read instructions out loud and have them build a strategy - Have them identify the components. Do not talk more, they will not be able to process it because they are overwhelmed, just help them code. Answer questions individually with your teacher assistants. "},{"id":2,"label":"Command Line Challenge","lessons":[{"title":"The Command Line (a.k.a: The Terminal) ","slug":"the-command-line-the-terminal"}],"project":{"title":"Command Line Challenge","instructions":"https://projects.breatheco.de/project/exercise-terminal-challenge"},"quizzes":[],"replits":[{"title":"Command line exercises","slug":"command-line-exercises","url":"https://cmdchallenge.com/"}],"homework":"Students must remember to read the next lesson before next class.","position":2,"assignments":[{"slug":"exercise-terminal-challenge","title":"Command Line Challenge"}],"description":"A text editor and the console - that's all you need to be a great coder. Time to master the second one.","key-concepts":["Most used CMD commands","File Directory Hierarchy","Relative vs Absolute Paths","Moving up...","Autocomplete with TAB","GIT in general"],"teacher_instructions":"Teach the command line to your students, use the CMD challenge to make it very fun! Start with a small explanation about the importance of the CMD and then explain each command after its respective challenge is completed ","extended_instructions":"# Command Line Interface Check if students were able to finish the Bootstrap Instagram ## `10 min` Small theory about the command line (do not explain the commands) ```md ⚠ ️IMPORTANT: Please don't explain every command, it is better if during the challenge the students find the commands in google or in the breathecode lesson. Students can do searches like: "How to get into a computer directory", etc. Force them to start searching in google!! ``` - Computers can be entirely managed without a windows interface, you can do everything from the command line. - Make sure to make students understand how important the command line (developers use it every day all the time and it is impossible to avoid). - Relative path vs absolute path. - Explain that we are in Gitpod, which uses ubuntu and we have to familiarize we the ubuntu command line. - Talk about the file hierarchy and how is represented in the command line, what the dot . and double dot .. represents. Draw on the board a file hierarchy and show if at the same time how the command line shows it (compare both). - Explain the use of the autocomplete command: [using tab one time for autocomplete or two times to show options](https://www.howtogeek.com/195207/use-tab-completion-to-type-commands-faster-on-any-operating-system/). - This is a [very good series of videos](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=AO0jzD1hpXc&t=267s&index=8&list=PL8A83A276F0D85E70) explaining the command line that students can **watch later.** - Share this [cheat sheet with the most used commands.](https://ucarecdn.com/61c6474b-5760-43db-9a2c-dfbea2ccdd76/Comandlinecheatsheet.pdf) ## `1:20 hr` Start The CMD Challenge - Have students create a project in Gitpod - Help them to clone the repo for the project (paste it in the slack channel so they can use the link)** 1. git init 2. git clone - Run the react presentation ```md 📝 The command line will make students practice the most important commands, explain each command after the each challenge is completed, the student that successfully completed it can explain to other students. ``` ## `1:30min` Take some time the class explaining git in a general way Git will be the first applicacion we will be using inside the command line, students must read about it and wat videos about it. ### What is git? Git is an online, central code storage that allows developers to manage a code base in teams. Some of the things you can do with git include: 1. You can collaborate on projects easily 2. see a history of revisions 3. Roll back to previous versions if a revision fails (version control) 4. Resolve code conflicts so that 2 developers don’t overwrite each other’s code. Git is a necessity to any developer working today as it’s resolved many of the issues of working on a team or keeping version history on a project. ## For Next Class Next class we will review GIT in more detail. Review the key concepts. Do a live demonstration on how to use Github, branches, resolve conflicts. Introduce students on how to contribute on Github by fixing misspells.","extended_instructions":"# First time using Git Last class you have introduced GitHub, students must have finish reading and watching videos and building their public profile with YML. ### About the GIT authentication: The academy does not want to explain much about GIT SSH Authentication because it can be a cumbersome concept for now, we strongly recomend always using HTTP during the course and let students learn about SSH later. ### The Commit Object Here is the lesson that talks about that: [https://content.breatheco.de/lesson/how-to-use-git-version-control-system#commit-objects](https://content.breatheco.de/lesson/how-to-use-git-version-control-system#commit-objects) Basically, a commit is a snapshot (picture) of what your project looked at during the moment of your commit. Commits represent a change in the current code, so if you don’t have any changes, you will receive a message saying there is nothing to commit. There are four main parts in a commit: 1. Set of files which make up your snapshot at that time 2. Instructions pointing to the Parent commit objects 3. An SH1 (hash) name that serves as a unique identifier for that specific commit. 4. Commits also typically have comments, which should explain what was changed or addressed in the current commit ### The HEAD The heads of the repository are like the "revision history of the project." A revision history is a list of commit objects that altogether contain all the changes that you and your other team members have made to the project files. Every time you make a new commit, the head will move to that new commit. (This way you are able to have access to the entire project history of commits.) It is possible to move the head to a different commit, however, you must remember that commits made after the commit to which the head is pointing at are not possible to be reviewed. ### The Stage When creating a commit, you select which files you wish to add to the commit. This is called "staging" your commit. (basically, preparing your formal commit object) Typically, you will use "git add ." which adds all files to your stage for the current commit, then follow it with your commit. ### Branch A branch allows you to work on a specific feature of code without compromising the main code in a repository. [http://content.breatheco.de/lesson/how-to-use-git-version-control-system#a-head-object-is-a-list-of-commits](http://content.breatheco.de/lesson/how-to-use-git-version-control-system#a-head-object-is-a-list-of-commits) That means that each branch is a separate revision history. The main branch of code in the repository is called "Master" typically You can have as many different branches as you want in a repository/project. Each branch has it’s own head which resides on the last commit of that branch. So if you have two branches, "Master" and “login”, each will have their own head on the last commit. When you are satisfied with the feature you developed, you can merge it back in to master and it will bring all code changes, along with replace the head on master with the new head. ### Typical Flow 1. All new projects have to be initialized with git. (git init) - This creates a git folder with all elements that define the git project. - At this point, it’s also good to set the remote for your project. This will tell the project what the address is for your repository so that you can push changes later. 2. the command for this is: git remote add origin https://github.com/user/repo.git 3. where the address at the end is your repository address or SSH address. 26. Whenever you have to stage your changes, you use "git add". As mentioned before, to add all file changes, “git add .” > Note: conversely, you can condense this into the git commit by adding a flag "-a" which means add all files to the commit stage 4. Once you made changes to your code and you are ready to commit: You create a commit object by using "git commit -m ‘commit message’" or if you have not used git add, you can use the -a flag as mentioned before. 5. At this point, you want to use ‘git push’ to upload your changes 6. If you need to create a new branch: - git checkout -b [branch name] - next you need to switch to that branch to work on it 3. git checkout [branch name] - when you complete your changes on a new branch, you merge the changes back in using the following: 4. git merge [other branch name] ## Commit vs PUSH We already discussed that a commit will allow you to create a new commit object. This is a local bundle you are preparing to upload. When you finish your commit, you have to attempt to upload that code to the repository. This is where git push comes in. It allows you to attempt to upload your changes to the repository. If there are any issues where a conflict has arisen, you will have to resolve the conflicts before pushing your changes. ## Resolving Conflicts For conflicts, git will notify you that there are issues. - this typically occurs when two people are trying to modify the same file(s). To proceed you need to: - Get the new changes downloaded to your computer with ‘git pull’ or if you are on a branch, ‘git pull origin branch-name’ - Then you will be asked to merge the changes - Here you will have to edit the files with conflicts and resolve any changes. - Once you have resolved the conflicts, you can attempt to push changes again. ## Start Coding With The Students! ** At this point we will start the assignment for the git collaborative portfolio project.** ** Break the class into groups and assign a section of the portfolio project** ** [https://github.com/breatheco-de/exercise-collaborative-html-website/blob/master/website1/designs/guide.jpg]**(https://github.com/breatheco-de/exercise-collaborative-html-website/blob/master/website1/designs/guide.jpg) * Use peer programming to complete the section quickly, then upload the changes to the repository your professor has provided. Teacher will clone the repo in a new class repository and will handle updating the name of the template parts so that the site functions properly. ### Students Homework: Finish all pending projects including todays."},{"id":5,"label":"Excuse Generator","lessons":[{"title":"What is JavaScript? Use float layout pursposes instead of display inline-block.","scrollY":0,"extended_instructions":"# Day 1 - The Internet, HTML and CSS ## `20 min` Small presentation about the bootcamp, [click here to open it](https://docs.google.com/presentation/d/1--0xX43xyfngGTWVQEgmcbLuE7QCCz-jovL2JBOEPY0/edit#slide=id.g555ffcabca_1_0). ## `15 min` Play a game to get to know each other. - Everyone writes in an anonimus piece of paper with something about themselves. E.g: "I like dogs" or "I work on sales", etc. - Put all papers inside a cup and start the game. - Choose one student to start introducing himself: - First name and last. - What would you like to be called? - What do you do now? (for work) - What do you plan on doing when you become a developer? - Then, that student must pick one random paper from the cup and guess how is the person that wrote it. - After guessing, the person who wrote it must come next and introduce himself and pick another paper... etc. ## `5 min` Present the team Everyone introduces himself: Chief of Admisions, Chief of Career Support, Chief of Education, Main instructor and teacher assistant. ## `20 min` Install and explain the tools ### Breathecode - Explain how breathecode works - How to start a new project. - The student journey (My Journey) divided in lessons, exercises, projects and quizzes. - The assignments (you can mark as done and you have to deliver the projects in order to graduate). - There is a search bar to search for particular content. ### Gitpod - Its a coding editor in the cloud. - Every project comes with a README.md file with instructions on how to use the boilerplate. - You can share your workspace snapshot with your teachers. - You connect using Gihub. - You will lose your workspaces if you don't PIN them. - Every time you open a workspace is a different computer. ### Slack - The cohort channel - The country channel (one for each country) - The Public support channel ## `20 min` Start today's explanation (introduction to the internet) ### How does the internet works? 1. The world is divided between servers and clients. 2. We call "clients" the computers with browsers or mobile apps. 3. We call servers where the centralized database is. ### HTTP Request vs Response** - The rules used for this client-sever communication is called HTTP, which stands for Hyper Text Transfer Protocol. - The way that you get the website is by sending a "Request" to the server. This tells the server what website or resource you are looking to view/use. The server then responds with the information. - The server then sends a response, which tells will confirm the receipt of the request and let your computer know that it will begin sending data. - This back and forth process will continue with more Request=>Response pairs until you have finished loading your remote resource. ### Everything is text! - With HTTP, it’s important to focus on the first T in the acronym, which stands for `Text`. In this protocol, everything is sent back and forth as TEXT. - While there are other protocols out there, for now, we want to remember that with HTTP – Everything is TEXT. - Make students open a picture with Notepad/TextEdit they will see the text that represents the image. ### Browser Interpretation - After your browser uses the HTTP protocol and receives the data as text, it then has the job of interpreting that text and converting it to the correct visual format. #### HTML - The first TEXT-based format we will see is HTML. - HTML its all about `` you open and close tags to give them basic format. - There are a lot of HTML tags but you only have to know a few and you can always google them. - Explain the basic tags like `

`,`

`,``,``, headings (`

`,`

`,etc). [[demo]] | :point_up: The most important thing to remember in HTML is to ALWAYS BE CLOSING! #### Always Be Closing and Indentation Matters** - Everything is going to be done in blocks of code. - First you open the block, then you close the block. ## `1 hr` Start the project! No more stalking, let the students do the talk now. They must plan a strategy for the project: - They must identify the tags that will be used for the exercise. - Students must gather in pairs and finish it together. ## `20 min` Help students add a stylesheet and explain the **basics of CSS** (next class you will talk about box model) Students are already overwhelmed, do not try to explain display/position/flex or box model. Explain only simple selectors: id, class and tag. And simple rules like color, background, etc. Make sure the are able to connect their stylesheet to the HTML, you can test making the `body{ background blue; }` - You can use CSS to select your HTML elements and apply styles to them. - Some basic selectors are: ID, CLASS, and ELEMENT - CSS formatting is always done as follows: ```css #id_selector { property: value; } .class_selector { property: value; } tag_selector { property: value; } ``` ### Selecting with class - You wll have to apply a class to the HMTL tag like this: ```html
``` - You can have more than classes per element if you like, separated by space. ## `Until the end of the day` HTML students finish the project. Students will be able to finish the instagram post and the postcard until the rest of the day. It's time to learn HTML and its structure","slug":"what-is-html-learn-html"},{"title":"Learn CSS: What is CSS Meant for?","slug":"what-is-css-learn-css"},{"title":"CSS Layouts: Create and Build Layouts with CSS","slug":"css-layouts"},{"title":"Mastering CSS Selectors","slug":"mastering-css-selectors"},{"title":"Bootstrap Tutorial: Learn Bootstrap 4 in 10 minutes","slug":"bootstrap-tutorial-of-bootstrap-4"}],"project":{"title":"Digital Postcard","instructions":"https://projects.breatheco.de/project/postcard"},"quizzes":[],"replits":[{"title":"Learn CSS Interactively","slug":"css-exercises"},{"title":"Learn HTML Forms","slug":"forms-exercises"},{"title":"Learn Bootstrap Tutorial","slug":"bootstrap-exercises"}],"homework":"Students must finish their project and must remember to read the next lesson before next class.","position":1,"assignments":["postcard","instagram-post","instagram-feed","instagram-feed-bootstrap"],"description":"During the pre-work you learn some basic CSS and HTML, and hopefully how to use the flex-box to create simple layouts. The first day we will review the pre-work completion and introduce a more evolved CSS that enables amazing layouts and the amazing Bootstrap framework that will make you life so much easier with the "component oriented" approach.","key-concepts":["Everything is text","Always be closing","Client vs Server","HTTP request vs response","HTML vs CSS","DRY Technique","Flex Box","Bootstrap","Component","Workflow: Identify Component, Copy&Paste, the customize it","Helper/utility Clasees that come with Bootstrap"],"teacher_instructions":"Students know already basic CSS and HTML, just go over the concepts really fast but stop and explain carefully the Display and Position rules, specifically talk about the FlexBox as the main tool to build layouts. Then, explain Bootstrap and how it solves 99% of the pain: everything is a component from now on"","extended_instructions":"# The Internet, HTML, CSS and Bootstrap ## `20 min` Small presentation about the bootcamp, [click here to open it](https://docs.google.com/presentation/d/1--0xX43xyfngGTWVQEgmcbLuE7QCCz-jovL2JBOEPY0/edit#slide=id.g555ffcabca_1_0). ## `15 min` Play a game to get to know each other. - Everyone writes in an anonimus piece of paper with something about themselves. E.g: "I like dogs" or "I work on sales", etc. - Put all papers inside a cup and start the game. - Choose one student to start introducing himself: - First name and last. - What would you like to be called? - What do you do now? (for work) - What do you plan on doing when you become a developer? - Then, that student must pick one random paper from the cup and guess how is the person that wrote it. - After guessing, the person who wrote it must come next and introduce himself and pick another paper... etc. ## `5 min` Present the team Everyone introduces himself: Chief of Admissions, Chief of Career Support, Chief of Education, Main instructor, and teacher assistant. ## `15 min` Install the tools Start with Gitpod, invite all students, and make sure they are able to create workspaces and what the academy boilerplates are. ## `10 min` Go over prework concepts really fast Check if the students completed the prework, if ~70% of the students finished the prework you can continue with the rest of the class, otherwise you will have to postpone today's topics and today's focus only con starting/completing the prework projects and concepts with the students. ## If 70% of the students completed the prework you can continue with the rest of the day: ### How does the internet works? 1. The world is divided between servers and clients. 2. We call "clients" the computers with browsers or mobile apps. 3. We call servers where the centralized database is. ### HTTP Request vs Response** - The rules used for this client-sever communication is called HTTP, which stands for Hyper Text Transfer Protocol. - The way that you get the website is by sending a "Request" to the server. This tells the server what website or resource you are looking to view/use. The server then responds with the information. - The server then sends a response, which tells will confirm the receipt of the request and let your computer know that it will begin sending data. - This back and forth process will continue with more Request=>Response pairs until you have finished loading your remote resource. ### Everything is text! - With HTTP, it’s important to focus on the first T in the acronym, which stands for `Text`. In this protocol, everything is sent back and forth as TEXT. - While there are other protocols out there, for now, we want to remember that with HTTP – Everything is TEXT. - Make students open a picture with Notepad/TextEdit they will see the text that represents the image. ### Browser Interpretation - After your browser uses the HTTP protocol and receives the data as text, it then has the job of interpreting that text and converting it to the correct visual format. #### HTML - The first TEXT-based format we will see is HTML. - HTML its all about `` you open and close tags to give them basic format. - There are a lot of HTML tags but you only have to know a few and you can always google them. - Explain the basic tags like `

`,`

`,``,``, headings (`

`,`

`,etc). [[demo]] | :point_up: The most important thing to remember in HTML is to ALWAYS BE CLOSING! #### Always Be Closing and Indentation Matters** - Everything is going to be done in blocks of code. - First you open the block, then you close the block. ### CSS vs HTML ```css #id_selector { property: value; } .class_selector { property: value; } tag_selector { property: value; } ``` ## `20 min` Start the new content: Advanced CSS ### Specificity - Do not use ID as CSS selectors (use specificity). - The class selector is the most used because it can be reused all over your website. - Show this [video that explains](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=In78mSOHmls) specificity to the class. - Combine selectors to get more specific about which element you are styling - Ask if anyone remembers what we said DRY Programming means? Don’t repeat yourself. You may think it’s funny that they call the opposite of DRY - WET programming, which they have given the following titles to: "write everything twice", "we enjoy typing" or "waste everyone's time"** ### Box Model - Box layout means that most elements can be thought of as boxes: with margin, padding, with and height. - There are 4 main parts to the typical box model: (draw the following on the board or show picture from breathcode) - Content: this is what is inside the box - Padding: this is spacing between the border and content (inside box also) - Border: this is the edge of the box - Margin: this is spacing between the outside of the box and the next element over in any direction. (which could be the edge of the page, another div, a paragraph, or even an image) - You can also have a background color or image, this will show in the content area of your box. #### The Display Property: - Compare `display:block` vs `display:inline`: Display block its what makes an element behave like a box, inline elements have no margins. - Compare `display:block` vs `display:inline-block`. - Display: flex; its the main tool for building complex layouts because it easily allows having several divs on the same line (columns). - I recommend going over the CSS and HTML [cheat sheets that we have available on the breathco.de platform under Assets](https://breatheco.de/assets/). ## Display Flex and how important it is. Take some time to explain display:flex and how it is used on today's project. #### The Position Property: - Position:fixed follows the user, it is mainly used for anoying modals or popups. - If one element has position:relative must always be companioned by one or more childs with position:absolute. Its broadly used for relating two elements to each other (one follows the other) - Compare `display:block` vs `display:inline-block`. ## `2:30 hr` Start the project! Read the instructions out loud with the class, make sure they understand. Students must start discussing on the whiteboard a strategy about the project. - From top to bottom identify the tags you will be using. - When to use `display:inline-block` and/or `position:absolute` or `position:relative`. - Setup the project with one `index.html` and one `styles.css` ## `20 min` Bootstrap ### What is bootstrap? Just a predefined stylesheet inveted by [a guy at twitter (Mark Otto)](https://twitter.com/mdo?lang=en). ### Why? - Because doing styles is repetitive, it was about time someone did a boilerplate. - Its component oriented. - It makes websites easier and faster to build. ### Bootstrap versions & download Bootstrap has many versions, always check if you are using the last version of Bootstrap on your project, here you can find all the available versions: [https://getbootstrap.com/docs/versions/](https://getbootstrap.com/docs/versions/) We recomend using a CDN to import bootstrap in your HTML like this one: [https://www.bootstrapcdn.com/](https://www.bootstrapcdn.com/) ### The Most Important (Used) Components 1. Navbar 2. Card 3. Modal: https://getbootstrap.com/docs/4.0/components/modal/#live-demo ### The Basic Workflow (asuming you have a wireframe or design) 1. Build your basic layout with the Grid (container, row and collumns) 1. Identify the components you will need (use piece of paper) 2. Copy & Paste the component code into your website. 3. Customize the component for your specific design. 4. Adjust anything else overriding with css styles on your own sylesheet. 5. Remember the utility classes to avoid doing to much custom CSS. ### Helper/Utility Classes that come with bootstrap* These are classes you can attach that do things such as control margin or padding, control borders, or even float elements. For example, if you wanted no margin on the left of the element, you can add the class ml-0 to the element and it will set the left margin to zero. ### Layout using Grid system - Explain 12 column layout and how it works - every line is a Row - this row holds columns as immediate childs - every Row on a page has 12 columns - columns are equally measured in percentages so they are responsive. - the basic sizes are: col, col-xs, col-sm, col-md, col-lg, col-xl ### Bootstrap does not have fonts or icons We use google fonts and font awesome for that. ## `2:30min` Have class work on bootstrap instagram. - Students gather in pairs tos strategize first (best practice) - Read instructions out loud and have them build a strategy - Have them identify the components. Do not talk more, they will not be able to process it because they are overwhelmed, just help them code. Answer questions individually with your teacher assistants. Then explain GIT without being very technical, the "Github for poets" video does a great explanation, we will get more technical the next class that we will collaborate on building a landing page.","extended_instructions":"# Welcome to Github

**Welcome everyone, Check if they were able to finish all the lessons, exercises, and projects up till now.**

### Explaining Github

1. As we mentioned in previous classes, Github & Git have become a staple of every development workflow.

2. You will use this in EVERY development job you have from here forward.

3. Show the main profile screen and explain parts

    - Use [https://github.com/gaearon](https://github.com/gaearon) as example.
    - Explain about the github activity graph, how github tracks your entire activity and other developers and recruiters can see it


4. Explain how to create a repository

    - click repository tab > new repo button > fill out data

5. Show what a repository looks like

   - explain the contents of the repository and the importance of the Readme file in a project.
   - Show popular repositories like react, vue, flask, etc. Show them the README files.
   - show [the git collaboration readme](https://github.com/breatheco-de/exercise-collaborative-html-website) as an example 

## The role of open-source

- Explain about open source, how the most important projects in the coding world are open source like: Chrome, Windows, React, Pyhton, Flask, Django, etc.

- In the open source world anyone can pull request anything, there are maintainers that review and approve changes.
- 4Geeks Academy syllabus is open source and you can Pull Request (lessons and projects)


## `1 hr` Project: Fixing Misspells as the perfect Open Source Ice-Breaker

Show students how every lesson on breathecode has the github logo on the top, and you can contrute or fix any lesson by clicking on the github logo and then editing the lesson file on github.
    
Create repositories for all previous workspaces and upload all your code to their corresponding repo’s. Then submit the assignments on your student.breatheco.de  **(DUE MONDAY). Also, work on all repl’its and get caught up. Be ready for the next class which is on Wireframing and design process.**

## `1hr` The student External Profile
